chapters.content:
Chapter 1 provides guidelines for determining whether appliances should be converted from oil or solid fuel to gas, and outlines installer responsibilities and code requirements.

FACTORS TO CONSIDER:

Not all appliances can or should be converted. Consult code requirements, manufacturer specifications, and local regulations while considering whether appliance should be converted or if existing conversion burner was properly installed. Important considerations when converting from oil or solid fuel to gas:

- Availability of gas
- Design of combustion chamber
- Appliance venting
- Appliance approval

For new installations, gas technician/fitter is responsible for determining acceptability of appliance, choosing correct burner, and doing installation. For existing installations, gas technician/fitter servicing converted appliance should assess whether conversion complied with legal requirements in effect at time of conversion and if it is still in compliance with current requirements and safety concerns.

BEFORE PROCEEDING:

Complete careful inspection of condition of appliance before removing parts from existing appliance. It is pointless to recommend conversion of unit when its general condition indicates that it is near end of its useful life. Moreover, if heating system is improperly sized or unit cannot perform in extremely cold weather, system itself requires improvements. Conversion to gas does not improve poorly designed systems.

FIVE MAIN FACTORS TO CONSIDER:

Unless all factors are in place and workable, it is pointless to begin conversion.

1. APPLIANCE APPROVAL:

Clause 4.2.1 of CSA B149.1, along with local regulations, requires that appliance be of type and rating approved for specific purpose for which it is employed. Unless appliance was originally approved for use with specific make and model of gas conversion burner, conversion may require reapproval of appliance by authority having jurisdiction (AHJ). If this is case, consider cost of field approval when making decision regarding feasibility of new conversion or decision to leave existing installation in operation.

Although legal and liability issues related to appliance approval are often most important factor in determining whether new conversion should be conducted, these issues were not usually considered before 1980, when most conversion burners were installed. Following "oil crisis" of 1973, when oil prices skyrocketed, many local authorities gave tacit approval for oil-to-gas conversions based on use of approved gas conversion burners installed in accordance with burner manufacturer instructions and code requirements established at that time.

2. AVAILABILITY OF NATURAL GAS/PROPANE:

Check with local gas company to ensure that natural gas supply line is available for area or if propane supply system can be installed.

3. DESIGN OF COMBUSTION CHAMBER:

Most suitable combustion chamber design for conversion is UPDRAFT TYPE.

Appliances having SEMI-REVERTIBLE FLUE are more difficult to convert satisfactorily, and burner selection is somewhat limited. Some heat exchanger designs are not suitable for conversion.

For example, when oil furnace is FULLY REVERTIBLE TYPE, having centreline of its flue outlet within 12 in (300mm) of burner port, Clause 7.8.1 of CSA B149.1 prohibits installation of conversion burner unless bypass is installed to allow gas that may build up in heat exchanger during failed trials-for-ignition to escape vent.

4. EFFICIENCY OF CURRENT APPLIANCE:

Oil and solid-fuel appliances operate with larger, more radiant flames than gas burners and, thus, produce larger amount of radiant heat transfer. To get maximum heat transfer from conversion, it is desirable to have maximum scrubbing of flue gas against heat exchanger areas. Units without secondary heat exchangers, shelves on top of unit, or potbelly design do not usually result in efficient conversions.

5. APPLIANCE VENTING:

Most oil and solid-fuel appliances vent to masonry chimney. Due to lower flue gas temperatures of gas firing, condensation can develop in oversized and unlined chimney. If chimney is in poor condition or it is not possible to install liner, new vent system must be installed as part of conversion.

Additionally, if soot has accumulated inside chimney flue, further arrangements have to be made to have chimney thoroughly cleaned out. Unless this is done, there is danger of soot drying out and falling down in large quantities, blocking vent connector.

THREE-PASS BOILER:

To increase efficiency, updraft boilers have multiple passes, such as three-pass boiler.

OTHER FACTORS TO CONSIDER:

OVERALL HEATING SYSTEM:
Questioning owner on efficiency of appliance may point to weak spots in system that cannot necessarily be improved with conversion. Some rooms may be poorly heated because of:
- Insufficient duct or register capacity
- Small radiators
- Incorrectly located thermostat

AGE OF APPLIANCE:
Oil-fired appliances that are more than ten years old should not be converted.

MANUFACTURER RECOMMENDATIONS:
Check with manufacturer before conversion since some units may specifically not be recommended for conversion.

INSTALLER'S RESPONSIBILITIES:

Success and continued safe operation of conversion burner installation depends great deal on quality of workmanship and care taken during initial burner installation.

Responsibility for safe and satisfactory installation rests with person who:
- Determines acceptability of appliance to be converted
- Specifies burner that is best suited for job
- Handles installation

In many cases, one person or organization, the installing contractor, assumes these responsibilities.

CODE REQUIREMENTS:

Clause 4.3 of CSA B149.1 clearly specifies installer's responsibilities during and after conversion. They must also comply with any amendments that local AHJ makes to Code.

4.3.1 INITIAL INSTALLATION:
"Before leaving installations, installers shall ensure that appliance, accessory, component, equipment, or piping and tubing they installed complies with Code requirements, and person initially activating appliance shall ensure that appliance is in safe working order."

4.3.2 USER INSTRUCTIONS:
"Installers shall instruct user in safe and correct operation of all appliances or equipment that they install."

4.3.3 MANUFACTURER INSTRUCTIONS:
"The installer shall ensure that manufacturer's instructions supplied with appliance are left with user."

4.3.4 REPLACEMENT PARTS:
"Before installing any replacement part of appliance, installer shall ensure that replacement part provides operational characteristics at least equivalent to those of original part."

4.3.5 APPLIANCE CONVERSION:
"When installation or conversion of appliance constitutes conversion from another form of energy, installer shall advise user of appliance, at time of installation or conversion, to have former form of energy either removed or left safe and secure from accidental activation."

User shall be advised for:
a) FUEL OIL SUPPLY TANK:
   i) Remove fill pipe, and cap or plug exposed fill pipe opening to inside tank
   ii) Shut off tank outlet valve, remove filter, and plug or cap valve outlet
   iii) Where tank located outdoors, disconnect all exposed piping or tubing, and cap or plug piping or tubing as close as practicable to tank

b) FUEL OIL CENTRAL DISTRIBUTING SYSTEM:
   i) Shut off fuel oil supply line valve located within building
   ii) Disconnect fuel oil supply line immediately downstream of meter, and cap or plug outlet of meter

c) PROPANE SYSTEM:
   i) Shut off cylinder or tank valve
   ii) Disconnect and cap or plug propane gas piping system [or tubing] outdoors

d) ELECTRICAL APPLIANCE:
   i) Shut off power supply to electrical appliance at switch
   ii) Ensure that overcurrent protection, fuse, or circuit breaker has been removed or put in off position

ONTARIO AMENDMENTS TO CLAUSE 4.3.5:
In Ontario, Clause 4.3.5 has been revoked and following substituted. When installation or conversion constitutes conversion from another form of energy, installer shall, at time of installation or conversion:

a) FUEL OIL TANK:
   i) Remove fill pipe and cap or plug exposed fill pipe opening to inside tank; however, do not remove tank vent pipe
   ii) Shut off tank outlet valve, remove filter, and plug or cap valve outlet
   iii) Where tank located outdoors, disconnect all exposed piping or tubing as close as practicable to tank; cap or plug exposed fill pipe opening to tank; however, do not remove tank vent pipe
   iv) Advise owner/operator of tank in writing that tank may be required to be removed in accordance with Fuel Oil Regulation and oil shall be removed by certificate holder trained for purpose

4.3.6 USER PROCEDURES:
"The installer installing installation or conversion, as specified in Clause 4.3.5, shall advise user of appliance in writing of procedures to be followed in discontinuing supply of former form of energy."

4.3.7 PIPING PRESSURE TEST:
"It shall be responsibility of installer of gas piping [or tubing] system to perform pressure tests in accordance with Clause 6.22.2 and to ensure that piping or tubing system is gas-tight at completion of tests."

4.3.8 GAS TIGHT TEST:
"It shall be responsibility of installer of appliance to perform tests in accordance with Clause 6.22.3 and to ensure that system is gas-tight at completion of tests."

CODE REQUIREMENTS - SPECIFIC SECTIONS:

APPROVAL (CLAUSE 4.2.1):
"An appliance, accessory, component, equipment, or material used in installation shall be of type and rating approved for specific purpose for which it is employed."

SUITABILITY OF USE (CLAUSE 4.5.3):
"When appliance is converted from gas or fuel specified on rating plate, conversion shall be in accordance with manufacturer's certified instructions. If there are no manufacturer's instructions for conversion of appliance, converted appliance shall be approved."

CONVERSIONS - MINIMUM CLEARANCES (CLAUSE 7.6.1):
"The minimum clearances from combustible material for boiler or furnace converted to gas shall be:
a) for boiler, as specified in Clause 7.1.3;
b) for forced-air furnace:
   i) from top (casing, bonnet, or plenum) — 1 in (25mm)
   ii) jacket sides and rear — 6 in (150mm)
   iii) front — 24 in (610mm)
c) for gravity furnace:
   i) vertical — 6 in (150mm)
   ii) sides and rear — 6 in (150mm)
   iii) front — 24 in (610mm), except as specified in Clause 4.13.2"

CONVERSION REQUIREMENTS (CLAUSE 7.6.2):
"An appliance to be converted shall be thoroughly cleaned, leak tested and examined for serviceability. Any unserviceable parts shall be repaired or replaced."

CHIMNEY REQUIREMENTS (CLAUSE 7.6.3):
"When existing vented appliance is to be converted from solid or liquid fuel, chimney shall be examined and shall meet requirements of Clauses 8.12.2 to 8.12.11."

CONVERSION BURNERS (CLAUSE 7.7.1):
"A conversion burner designed by manufacturer of appliance to be converted, or burner compatible with appliance to be converted, shall be used."

MOBILE HOMES (CLAUSE 7.7.2):
"When oil-fired furnace in mobile home is converted to gas, conversion shall be by means of:
a) furnace manufacturer's certified burner conversion package; or
b) certified conversion burner, provided that:
   i) it is compatible with furnace and its installation
   ii) basic design of furnace is not altered
   iii) when adjusted, burner firing rate does not exceed furnace manufacturer's specified firing rate"

FLAME IMPINGEMENT (CLAUSE 7.7.3):
"A conversion burner shall be correctly positioned and firmly secured to eliminate direct flame impingement on any surface other than flame spreader."

REVERTIBLE FLUE FURNACE INSTALLATION (CLAUSE 7.8.1):
"A revertible flue furnace shall not be converted by installation of:
a) natural-draft burner, unless:
   i) centreline of flue collar is at least 12 in (300mm) above burner port
   ii) flue outlet is extended to permit installation of draft hood or draft regulator so that relief opening is at least 12 in (300mm) above highest flue pass
   iii) bypass at least 1 in (25mm) in diameter is connected to top of highest flue pass and extends through outer casing, terminating in vent connector. Direct draft damper may be used as alternative to bypass; or

b) fan-assisted burner, unless:
   i) there is compliance with requirements of Items a) i) to iii); or
   ii) there is compliance with requirements of Items a) i) and ii), and burner incorporates spark ignition, pre-purge, and automatic valve with integral dual safety shut-off feature"

BYPASS REQUIREMENTS (CLAUSE 7.8.2):
"The bypass referred to in Item a) iii) of Clause 7.8.1 shall be gas-tight and shall be constructed of metal at least equivalent in strength and corrosion resistance to metal from which it is extended."

SECONDARY HEATING SURFACES (CLAUSE 7.8.3):
"A forced-air furnace with secondary heating surface located on suction side of circulating air blower shall not be converted to gas except where such heating surface consists of single cylindrical flue pipe passing directly from primary heat exchanger to flue collar and having single continuously gas-tight welded joint."

MARKINGS (CLAUSE 7.8.4):
"An easily readable caution sign or label of durable material having black letters on yellow background shall be either on or attached to each side of circulating air blower compartment access door of fuel converted forced-air furnace and shall be worded as follows:

'WARNING: THIS COMPARTMENT MUST BE CLOSED EXCEPT WHEN SERVICING'
'AVERTISSEMENT : CE COMPARTMENT EST OBLIGÉ DE RESTER FERMÉ, SAUF POUR L'ENTRETIEN'

The lettering of 'WARNING' and 'AVERTISSEMENT' shall be minimum of 3/8 in (9.6mm) in height, and remainder of lettering shall be in minimum of 3/16 in (4.8mm) in height."

FLUE OUTLET MATERIAL (CLAUSE 7.8.5):
"The flue outlet referred to in Clause 7.8.1 shall be made of material at least equivalent in strength and corrosion resistance to that of No. 24 GSG (0.60mm) galvanized steel."

TEMPERATURE LIMITS (CLAUSE 7.8.6):
"An automatically controlled gravity or forced-air furnace shall be equipped with high-temperature limit control, and maximum setting of control shall be:
a) 350°F (175°C) for gravity furnace; and
b) 250°F (120°C) for forced-air furnace."

VENT CONNECTOR (CLAUSE 8.18.11):
"Except as provided in Clause 8.18.13, minimum clearance of vent connector of other than Type B vent material from combustible wall or partition shall be in accordance with Table 8.6."

CONVERTED FURNACE OR BOILER (CLAUSE 8.18.18):
"A vent connector of either Type B or Type L vent material shall not be used between flue outlet and draft-control device of either converted furnace or converted boiler."

DRAFT HOOD LOCATION (CLAUSE 8.23.6):
"A draft hood shall be in same room as combustion air opening of appliance. Draft hood shall not be installed in false ceiling space, in room other than one appliance serves, or in any manner that could permit difference in pressure between draft-hood relief opening and combustion air supply. Draft hood supplied for conversion burner shall be located so that burner is capable of safe and efficient operation."

DRAFT REGULATORS (CLAUSE 8.25):
"A draft regulator, when used, shall be located so that relief opening is not obstructed by any part of appliance or adjacent construction. When used with incinerator, draft regulator shall be of single-acting type. In all other installations, it shall be of double-acting type."

IMPORTANT: Oil and solid-fuel appliances are usually equipped with single-acting draft regulator. When converting such appliance, replace or adjust draft regulator to function as double-acting type.

chapters.content:
Chapter 2 covers preparing appliances for conversion and choosing appropriate conversion burners.

PREPARING THE APPLIANCE:

SMOKE TEST:
Purpose: To check venting system for proper operation

WATER TEST:
Purpose: To check boiler heat exchanger for leaks

FLUE OUTLET:
Must be plugged before smoke test is performed.

HEAT EXCHANGER CRACKS:
If cracks are discovered in heat exchanger of furnace, heat exchanger or appliance must be replaced. Repairs by welding, furnace cement, or high-temperature silicone are NOT permitted.

AFTER APPLIANCE CHECKED AND REPAIRED:
Check combustion air and venting system before mounting burner, selecting proper orifice size, or selecting proper burner air tube.

MASONRY CHIMNEYS:
Most masonry chimneys used for oil burners are too large and should have liner installed for gas conversion.

ADJUSTABLE BAROMETRIC DRAFT CONTROL DEVICE:
Cannot be located in separate room from appliance. Must be in same room as appliance.

DOUBLE SWING BAROMETRIC DAMPER:
Preferred location is on vent connector. Other correct locations exist, but some locations are incorrect (such as too close to appliance or downstream of reducer).

CHOOSING A CONVERSION BURNER:

There are numerous criteria for selecting correct conversion burner:
- Basic design of appliance (combustion chamber size and shape)
- Input requirement
- Type of gas

When selecting specific type of burner, investigate capabilities of burner since design variations among manufacturers provide varying performance levels for same type of burner. Most common gas conversion burners are made by same manufacturers of oil burners and look similar.

Review manufacturer specifications and recommendations before specifying any particular burner model. Each conversion burner should bear seal of approved testing body certifying compliance with CSA ANSI Z21.8.

TYPES OF CONVERSION BURNERS:

There are two main types of conversion burners, classified according to how combustion air is distributed:

1. NATURAL-DRAFT (ATMOSPHERIC) BURNERS:
Use combustion air naturally supplied to combustion chamber

CSA B149.1 defines natural-draft burner as "burner that is not equipped with mechanical device for supplying combustion air".

There are two main types of atmospheric burners designed to provide required flame geometry (shape of flame):
- Upshot
- Inshot

UPSHOT BURNER:
Upshot burner fires vertically with flame being diverted by spreader. Flame is generally circular in shape and has uniform cross-section.

This type of burner is mainly used with furnaces or boilers originally manufactured for coal-burning use. By removing grates and ashpit doors, conversion burner can be installed in ashpit section, and flame spreader distributes heat from firepot up to dome and heating surfaces.

Atmospheric upshot burner design consists of series of ports, slots, or ribbons whereby flames fire vertically — generally uniform in height — in combustion chamber.

Components:
- Runner tube igniter
- Stainless steel flame deflector
- Telescoping venturi
- Adjustable legs
- Secondary air adjustment

INSHOT BURNER:
Inshot burner fires horizontally into combustion chamber. It may have spreader or target plate downstream of burner head to direct flame.

Inshot conversion burners are mainly intended to replace oil burners. Oil burners are generally flange-mounted and fire into refractory or stainless steel combustion chamber within furnace body.

Components:
- Stainless steel flame spreader
- Primary air shutter
- Adjusting mounting flange

2. POWER BURNERS:
Power burners come with mechanical device, such as fan or blower, to provide pressurized combustion air to burner. This allows better control of combustion process and high input for given volume of combustion space. Pressure at which air is delivered, as well as burner design, provide flame geometry.

TYPES OF POWER BURNERS:

LOW-PRESSURE UPSHOT (FAN-ASSIST BURNER):
- Fires vertically into combustion zone with generally round and symmetrical flame
- Combustion air supplied at pressure sufficient to overcome resistance of burner only

LOW-PRESSURE INSHOT (FAN-ASSIST BURNER):
- Fires horizontally into combustion zone
- Combustion air supplied at pressure sufficient to overcome resistance of burner only

HIGH-PRESSURE INSHOT (FORCED-DRAFT BURNER):
- Fires horizontally into combustion zone
- Combustion air supplied at pressure sufficient to overcome resistance of burner AND appliance

BURNER SELECTION CRITERIA:

Before reaching final decision as to what burner is best suited for appliance, consider following conditions to ensure proper selection and application:
- Firing rate (input range) of burner
- Flue gas travel
- Combustion chamber geometry

FIRING RATE:
To determine input requirement, you must know amount of heat required to heat building. With older oil-to-gas conversions, heat loss of building is rarely available. Therefore, firing rate of existing fuel can be converted to gas input.

CONVERSION FACTORS:
- Natural gas: 1000 Btu/ft³
- Propane: 2500 Btu/ft³
- No. 2 fuel oil: 140,000 Btu per US gallon (33,475 Btu/L)

IMPORTANT: Since gas burner is less efficient, conversion burner with 30% greater input (than previous oil burner) should be selected to avoid flue gas condensation.

MAXIMUM PERMISSIBLE FIRING RATES FOR ATMOSPHERIC BURNERS:

Tables provide maximum firing rates based on:
- Round grates (by diameter): 14 in to 28 in (75,000 to 300,000 Btu/h)
- Rectangular grates (by area): 18×18 in to 24×28 in (165,000 to 300,000 Btu/h)

Once you have determined input, you can set manifold pressure and orifice size according to manufacturer input tables.

FLUE GAS TRAVEL:

Oil and solid-fuel appliances have three basic modes of flue gas travel:

UPDRAFT:
- Flue gas travel is constantly upward, with flue products exiting at or very near highest point of heat exchanger
- All burner types may be considered for this conversion

SEMI-REVERTIBLE:
- Flue gas travel is upward initially, then downward to exit appliance
- Centreline of flue outlet is 12 in (30cm) or more above burner port level
- Some atmospheric and all power burners may be considered for this conversion

REVERTIBLE:
- Flue gas travel is upward initially, then downward to exit appliance
- Centreline of flue outlet is located less than 12 in (30cm) above burner port level
- Revertible appliances are only to be converted according to Clause 7.8.1 of CSA B149.1

COMBUSTION CHAMBER GEOMETRY:

Certain types of burners are better adapted to one boiler than another.

For example, where short fireboxes are encountered, it is often better to use burner with higher heat release and avoid long flames that impinge upon metal surfaces. Similarly, geometry of burner flame should match that of combustion chamber whenever possible (i.e., round flame for round chamber, elongated flame for rectangular chamber).

TWO BASIC TYPES OF CHAMBER GEOMETRY:

TYPE A DESIGNS:
- Combustion chambers at base of heating zone
- Heat transfer surfaces: Below and above flame level

TYPE B DESIGNS:
- Combustion chambers and heat exchangers on supporting base
- Heat transfer surfaces: Above flame level only

IMPORTANT: For Type B combustion chambers, inshot burners are acceptable only if combustion chamber liner and insulation are installed.

MOUNTING FLANGES:

Burner air tube may be available in different lengths or with adjustable flange. Length of air tube must be selected according to instructions provided by manufacturer of boiler, and it must match thickness of boiler wall complete with its insulation.

AIR TUBE AND MOUNTING PLATE SIZING:

Select air tube and mounting plate sized so that end of air tube is flushed with, or no more than 1/4 in short of, inside of appliance combustion chamber front wall when burner is mounted. If it extends into combustion chamber, there may be damage from overheating. Seal between burner and boiler must be airtight.

chapters.content:
Chapter 3 provides comprehensive burner selection tables organized by appliance manufacturer, along with combustion testing requirements and troubleshooting information.

BURNER SELECTION TABLES:

Extensive tables are provided showing burner compatibility for appliances from numerous manufacturers. Tables include:

APPLIANCE INFORMATION:
- Appliance model number
- Burner model recommendation
- Diffuser/head type
- Air tube specifications
- OEM air tube part numbers
- Insertion depth requirements

BURNER SPECIFICATIONS:
- Input MBH (thousand Btu/h)
- Orifice size (decimal equivalents)
- Air setting (percentages or specific configurations)
- Air band positions
- Head bar settings
- Air shutter positions
- Manifold pressure for natural gas
- Manifold pressure for propane

SPECIAL NOTES:
- Manufacturer-specific front plates (with order information)
- Required gasket and grommet kits
- Air flow switch cover spacers
- Universal air tube applications
- Covers and cabinet compatibility

MANUFACTURERS INCLUDED:
Tables cover conversion specifications for appliances from:
- Peerless (SC/SCT, WBV, Pensotti DK2, S1/BL series)
- Slant Fin (L/LD, TR, EC, XL series)
- Smith Cast-Iron Boilers (Series 8, 19A, Solaia)
- Southern Breeze
- Thermo-Dynamics (CWL-GS, EMG, HT, PK, SPK, TDX, VT series)
- Thermo Pride (OH6)
- Triad (900SH)

- Williamson-Thermoflo (W/HBO, CHB, CLB, PMP/PLB)
- York Shipley (CT series)

DRILL SIZE DECIMAL EQUIVALENTS:

Comprehensive conversion table provided showing:
- Fractional sizes (1/64" to 1")
- Decimal equivalents (0.0156 to 1.0000)
- Drill number sizes (#60 to #1)
- Letter drill sizes (A to Z)

This allows precise orifice selection and verification.

COMBUSTION TESTING:

BREECHING PIPE:
Flue gas exhaust pipe that connects downstream of draft regulator or penetrates chimney (not roof penetration, not direct appliance connection).

NET STACK TEMPERATURE:
Describes difference in temperature between flue gas in vent and ambient air. Critical for determining heat loss and appliance efficiency.

INCOMPLETE COMBUSTION:
If appliance is firing at correct input, primary cause of incomplete combustion is lack of air (not lack of gas, too much air, or too much gas).

PERFECT COMBUSTION:
Perfect combustion cannot be maintained in combustion chamber. Always some level of incomplete combustion or excess air.

PRODUCTS OF COMPLETE COMBUSTION:
- Heat
- Carbon dioxide (CO2)
- Water vapour (H2O)
- Nitrogen (N2)

COMBUSTION AIR REQUIREMENTS:
For perfect (theoretical) combustion:
- Natural gas: 10 ft³ of air per ft³ of natural gas
- Propane: 25 ft³ of air per ft³ of propane

FLUE GAS ANALYSIS:

OXYGEN (O2):
Element in flue gas analysis that best indicates how much excess air is being introduced into combustion chamber. Higher O2 = more excess air.

CARBON DIOXIDE (CO2):
For flue gas analysis of natural gas, 7.5% reading for both CO2 and O2 indicates approximately 50% excess air.

APPLIANCE EFFICIENCY:
If appliance is 100% efficient, temperature of flue gas will be room temperature (all heat extracted before gases exit). In reality:
- 130°F (54°C) is very efficient
- 325°F (205°C) is typical for many appliances
- 3550°F (1950°C) is flame temperature (0% efficiency)

CARBON MONOXIDE (CO):
Carbon monoxide must remain at 0 ppm on air-free basis for perfect combustion. Acceptable limit is 20 ppm. Levels of 50 ppm or 100 ppm indicate problems.

Without sufficient air for combustion in gas-fired appliance, you would expect to find carbon monoxide in products of combustion (not ethane, oxygen, or hydrogen sulphide).

BAROMETRIC DAMPER ADJUSTMENT:

In order to achieve neutral pressure point at burner, barometric damper should be adjusted to approximately 0 to -0.02 in w.c. (or -0.02 to -0.04 in w.c. as acceptable range).

FLUE GAS COOLING:

During combustion of natural gas, if combustion products in vent are cooled down below 120°F (49°C), following condition would occur:

Flue products would condense and corrode the vent (not increase CO quantity, increase CO2 quantity, or cause carbon condensation and soot plugging, though these may be secondary effects).

Factors to Consider Before 
Conversion
Before proceeding with the removal of parts from the existing appliance, 
complete a careful inspection of the condition of the appliance.
It is pointless to recommend the conversion of a unit when its general 
condition indicates that it is near the end of its useful life. Moreover, if the 
heating system is improperly sized or the unit cannot perform in 
extremely cold weather, the system itself requires improvements. A 
conversion to gas will not improve poorly designed systems.
The information below describes the five main factors to consider before 
conversion. Unless all factors are in place and workable, it is pointless to 
begin the conversion.
Factor 1: Appliance Approval
Code Requirements
Clause 4.2.1 of CSA B149.1, along with local regulations, 
requires that an appliance be of the type and rating 
approved for the specific purpose for which it is employed.
Re-approval Considerations
Unless the appliance was originally approved for use with a 
specific make and model of gas conversion burner, the 
conversion may require re-approval of the appliance by the 
authority having jurisdiction. If this is the case, consider the 
cost of a field approval when making a decision regarding 
the feasibility of a new conversion or a decision to leave an 
existing installation in operation.
Historical Context of 
Appliance Approval
Although the legal and liability issues related to appliance approval are 
often the most important factor in determining whether a new 
conversion should be conducted, these issues were not usually 
considered before 1980, when most conversion burners were installed.
Following the "oil crisis" of 1973, when oil prices skyrocketed, many local 
authorities gave tacit approval for oil-to-gas conversions based on the 
use of approved gas conversion burners installed in accordance with 
burner manufacturer's instructions and Code requirements established 
at that time.
Factor 2: Availability of 
Natural Gas/Propane
Check with the local gas company to ensure that a natural gas supply line 
is available for the area or that a propane supply system can be installed.
Natural Gas Supply
Verify the presence of a natural 
gas supply line in the conversion 
area.
Propane System 
Installation
Confirm the feasibility of installing 
a propane supply system if natural 
gas is unavailable.
Factor 3: Design of 
Combustion Chamber - 
Updraft Type
The most suitable combustion chamber design for conversion is the 
updraft type shown in Figure 1-1(a).
Appliances having a semi-revertible flue [Figure 1-1(b)] are more difficult 
to convert satisfactorily and burner selection is somewhat limited. Some 
heat exchanger designs are not suitable for conversion.
Factor 3: Design of 
Combustion Chamber - 
Revertible Type Restrictions
For example, when an oil furnace is a fully revertible type [Figure 1-1(c)], 
having the centreline of its flue outlet within 12 inches (300 mm) of the 
burner port, Clause 7.8.1 of the CSA B149.1 prohibits the installation of a 
conversion burner unless a bypass is installed to allow gas that may build 
up in the heat exchanger during failed trials-for-ignition to escape the 
vent.
•
Centreline of flue outlet within 12 inches (300 mm) of burner port.
•
Requires a bypass for gas escape during failed ignition trials.
•
Prohibited without bypass installation.
Factor 4: Efficiency of 
Current Appliance
Oil and solid-fuel appliances operate with larger, more radiant flames 
than gas burners and, thus, produce a larger amount of radiant heat 
transfer. To get the maximum heat transfer from a conversion, it is 
desirable to have a maximum scrubbing of the flue gas against the heat 
exchanger areas.
Units without secondary heat exchangers, shelves on top of the unit, or a 
pot-belly design do not usually result in efficient conversions.
Updraft Boiler Efficiency
To increase efficiency, updraft boilers will have multiple passes, such as 
the three-pass boiler shown in Figure 1-2.
This design maximizes heat transfer by increasing the contact time 
between flue gases and heat exchanger surfaces.
Factor 5: Appliance Venting - Chimney Condition
Most oil and solid-fuel appliances vent to a masonry chimney. Due to the lower flue gas temperatures of gas firing, 
condensation can develop in an oversized and unlined chimney. If the chimney is in poor condition, or if it is not possible to 
install a liner, a new vent system must be installed as part of the conversion.

Factors to Consider Before Conversion
Before proceeding with the removal of parts from the existing appliance, complete a careful inspection of the condition of the appliance.
It is pointless to recommend the conversion of a unit when its general condition indicates that it is near the end of its useful life. Moreover, if the heating system is improperly sized or the unit cannot perform in extremely cold weather, the system itself requires improvements. A conversion to gas will not improve poorly designed systems.
The information below describes the five main factors to consider before conversion. Unless all factors are in place and workable, it is pointless to begin the conversion.
Factor 1: Appliance Approval
Code Requirements
Clause 4.2.1 of CSA B149.1, along with local regulations, requires that an appliance be of the type and rating approved for the specific purpose for which it is employed.
Re-approval Considerations
Unless the appliance was originally approved for use with a specific make and model of gas conversion burner, the conversion may require re-approval of the appliance by the authority having jurisdiction. If this is the case, consider the cost of a field approval when making a decision regarding the feasibility of a new conversion or a decision to leave an existing installation in operation.
Historical Context of Appliance Approval
Although the legal and liability issues related to appliance approval are often the most important factor in determining whether a new conversion should be conducted, these issues were not usually considered before 1980, when most conversion burners were installed.
Following the "oil crisis" of 1973, when oil prices skyrocketed, many local authorities gave tacit approval for oil-to-gas conversions based on the use of approved gas conversion burners installed in accordance with burner manufacturer's instructions and Code requirements established at that time.
Factor 2: Availability of Natural Gas/Propane
Check with the local gas company to ensure that a natural gas supply line is available for the area or that a propane supply system can be installed.
Natural Gas Supply
Verify the presence of a natural gas supply line in the conversion area.
Propane System Installation
Confirm the feasibility of installing a propane supply system if natural gas is unavailable.
Factor 3: Design of Combustion Chamber - Updraft Type
The most suitable combustion chamber design for conversion is the updraft type shown in Figure 1-1(a).
Appliances having a semi-revertible flue [Figure 1-1(b)] are more difficult to convert satisfactorily and burner selection is somewhat limited. Some heat exchanger designs are not suitable for conversion.
Factor 3: Design of Combustion Chamber - Revertible Type Restrictions
For example, when an oil furnace is a fully revertible type [Figure 1-1(c)], having the centreline of its flue outlet within 12 inches (300 mm) of the burner port, Clause 7.8.1 of the CSA B149.1 prohibits the installation of a conversion burner unless a bypass is installed to allow gas that may build up in the heat exchanger during failed trials-for-ignition to escape the vent.
Centreline of flue outlet within 12 inches (300 mm) of burner port.
Requires a bypass for gas escape during failed ignition trials.
Prohibited without bypass installation.
Factor 4: Efficiency of Current Appliance
Oil and solid-fuel appliances operate with larger, more radiant flames than gas burners and, thus, produce a larger amount of radiant heat transfer. To get the maximum heat transfer from a conversion, it is desirable to have a maximum scrubbing of the flue gas against the heat exchanger areas.
Units without secondary heat exchangers, shelves on top of the unit, or a pot-belly design do not usually result in efficient conversions.
Updraft Boiler Efficiency
To increase efficiency, updraft boilers will have multiple passes, such as the three-pass boiler shown in Figure 1-2.
This design maximizes heat transfer by increasing the contact time between flue gases and heat exchanger surfaces.
Factor 5: Appliance Venting - Chimney Condition
Most oil and solid-fuel appliances vent to a masonry chimney. Due to the lower flue gas temperatures of gas firing, condensation can develop in an oversized and unlined chimney. If the chimney is in poor condition, or if it is not possible to install a liner, a new vent system must be installed as part of the conversion.
Condensation Risk
Lower flue gas temperatures from gas firing can lead to condensation in oversized/unlined chimneys.
Chimney Condition
Poor chimney condition or inability to install a liner necessitates a new vent system.
